section.title: Introduction
section.p: This document defines Avro IDL, a higher-level language for authoring Avro schemata. Before reading this document, you should have familiarity with the concepts of schemata and protocols, as well as the various primitive and complex types available in Avro.

section.title: Purpose
section.p: The aim of the Avro IDL language is to enable developers to author schemata in a way that feels more similar to common programming languages like Java, C++, or Python. Additionally, the Avro IDL language may feel more familiar for those users who have previously used the interface description languages (IDLs) in other frameworks like Thrift, Protocol Buffers, or CORBA.

section.title: Imports
section.p: Files may be imported in one of three formats:

ul.li: An IDL file may be imported with a statement like: import idl "foo.avdl";
A JSON protocol file may be imported with a statement like: import protocol "foo.avpr";
A JSON schema file may be imported with a statement like: import schema "foo.avsc";

section.p: Messages and types in the imported file are added to this file's protocol.
Imported file names are resolved relative to the current IDL file.

section.title: Defining an Enumeration
section.p: Enums are defined in Avro IDL using a syntax similar to C or Java. An Avro Enum supports optional default values. In the case that a reader schema is unable to recognize a symbol written by the writer, the reader will fall back to using the defined default value. This default is only used when an incompatible symbol is read. It is not used if the enum field is missing.

section.title: Primitive Types
section.p: The primitive types supported by Avro IDL are the same as those supported by Avro's JSON format. This list includes int, long, string, boolean, float, double, null, and bytes.

section.title: Default Values
section.p: Default values for fields may be optionally specified by using an equals sign after the field name followed by a JSON expression indicating the default value. This JSON is interpreted as described in the spec.

section.title: Arrays
section.p: Array types are written in a manner that will seem familiar to C++ or Java programmers. An array of any type t is denoted array<t>. For example, an array of strings is denoted array<string>, and a multidimensional array of Foo records would be array<array<Foo>>.

section.title: Maps
section.p: Map types are written similarly to array types. An array that contains values of type t is written map<t>. As in the JSON schema format, all maps contain string-type keys.

section.title: Comments
section.p: Comments that begin with /** are used as the documentation string for the type or field definition that follows the comment.
